description: An edible fruit of a number of species of trees in the genus Diospyros. The most widely cultivated of these is the Oriental persimmon, Diospyros kaki. Persimmons are typically orange or reddish-orange, and can be astringent (mouth-puckering until fully ripe and soft, like Hachiya) or non-astringent (can be eaten crisp like an apple, like Fuyu).
healthBenefits: Good source of Vitamin A and Vitamin C.
Rich in dietary fiber, aiding digestion.
Contains antioxidants like carotenoids, flavonoids, and tannins.
May help lower cholesterol and support heart health.

potentialAllergies.name: Astringency
potentialAllergies.details: Astringent varieties (like Hachiya) are very unpleasant to eat before fully ripe due to high tannin content, causing a dry, puckering sensation. Non-astringent varieties (like Fuyu) do not have this issue.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Climate: Temperate to subtropical. Some varieties require winter chill.
2. Soil: Well-drained, loamy soil. Adaptable but prefers pH 6.0-7.5.
3. Propagation: Grafting is common for commercial varieties.
4. Planting: Plant in full sun.
5. Watering: Regular watering, especially for young trees and during fruit development.
6. Harvesting: Harvest when fruits are fully colored. Astringent types must be allowed to soften completely (almost jelly-like) before eating. Non-astringent types can be eaten while firm or slightly soft.
growthDuration: Trees may start bearing fruit in 3-7 years. Fruits ripen in autumn and early winter.
sustainabilityTips: Know your persimmon type: Fuyu (non-astringent) can be eaten firm like an apple. Hachiya (astringent) must be very soft before eating.
Store at room temperature to ripen. Ripe persimmons can be refrigerated.
carbonFootprintInfo: Moderate, depending on origin and transport (0.5-1.0 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Eating Fresh Persimmons (Fuyu type)
steps: Wash the Fuyu persimmon. The skin is edible.
You can eat it like an apple, biting directly into it, or slice it.
Remove the core/calyx (leafy top) if desired.
Slices can be added to salads, cheese boards, or eaten as a snack.

staticRecipes.name: Persimmon and Pomegranate Salad
staticRecipes.description: A vibrant autumn salad with sweet persimmons and tart pomegranate seeds.
ingredients: 2 ripe Fuyu persimmons, peeled (optional) and sliced or diced
Dressing: 2 tbsp olive oil, 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar, 1 tsp honey, salt and pepper to taste
steps: In a large bowl, combine mixed greens, persimmon slices/dices, pomegranate arils, and toasted nuts.
In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, apple cider vinegar, honey, salt, and pepper.
Drizzle dressing over the salad and toss gently. Serve immediately.

staticRecipes.name: Baked Persimmon (Hachiya type, when very ripe)
staticRecipes.description: A simple way to enjoy the custardy sweetness of fully ripe astringent persimmons.
ingredients: 1-2 very ripe Hachiya persimmons (should feel like a water balloon)
Optional: a sprinkle of cinnamon, a dollop of yogurt or cream
steps: Ensure Hachiya persimmons are extremely soft and ripe to avoid astringency.
Cut the persimmons in half horizontally or remove the top calyx.
Place cut-side up in a small baking dish.
Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until heated through and slightly caramelized.
Serve warm. You can scoop out the pulp with a spoon. Add cinnamon or serve with yogurt/cream if desired.
